wikipedia_page.main: Arabella Katherine Hankey (12 January 1834 – 9 May 1911) was an English missionary and nurse who is best known for being the author of the poem The Old, Old Story, from which the hymns "Tell me the old, old story" and "I Love to Tell the Story" were derived.

response: #"I Love to Tell the Story" – 2:53 (William G. Fischer, Katherine Hankey)

link_mentions.page: Tell Me the Old, Old Story
response: "Tell Me the Old, Old Story" is a hymn.  The words were written as a poem by Katherine Hankey, an English evangelist, in 1866, while she was recovering from a serious illness in London.  It was set to music by William Hovard Doane, who was much impressed by the poem when it was recited by Major General David Russell while they were attending an international convention of the YMCA in Montreal in 1867.

link_mentions.page: I Love to Tell the Story, A Hymns Collection
response: # "I Love to Tell the Story" (William Fischer, Katherine Hankey) – 1:40

link_mentions.page: I Love to Tell the Story
response: thumb|right|240px|Katherine Hankey, lyricist for "I Love to Tell the Story"
"I Love to Tell the Story" is a well-known hymn which was written as a poem by an English evangelist, Katherine Hankey. It was set to music by William G. Fischer.
